results.title: And justice for all [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Norman Jewison, Patrick Palmer and Columbia Pictures
results.brief_description: Al Pacino plays Arthur Kirkland, an attorney who experiences firsthand corruption of the establishment that he works for. Burdened with the memory of clients who’ve suffered heinously at the hands of inefficient bureaucracy, Kirkland starts to realise how systemic the depravity is among his colleagues. Whilst defending a repulsive judge (whom he loathes for personal reasons) on a rape and battery charge, Kirkland is forced to decide whether or not he will become another a cog in the amoral wheel of justice. For Pacino this role was one of several he played in unsettling dramas, produced in the 1970s, that addressed urban angst, endemic judicial venality and the demise of the American dream. Directed by prolific Canadian filmmaker Norman Jewison (Fiddler on the roof, Moonstruck, Rollerball, Iceman, Jesus Christ Superstar), whose films have at times addressed issues of racial injustice in America (In the heat of the night, A Soldiers story, The Hurricane). Conceived as a satire, the screenplay for the film was co-written by director Barry Levinson, who along with Valerie Curtin was nominated for an Academy Award.

results.title: Anastasia
results.creator_credit: Anatole Litvak, Buddy Adler and Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation
results.brief_description: The story is based on a factual account of the mystery that surrounded the Russian princess Anastasia, youngest daughter of Tzar Nicholas II, who along with her family was imprisoned and shot after the 1917 revolution.

constellations_other.name: The spectre of the Romanovs
constellations_other.description: The Romanov dynasty has become a symbol of opulence throughout popular culture. Their final costume ball is even referenced in the coronation mood boards for Tony McNamara's The Great. Let's look at their history on-screen.

results.creator_credit_for_label: Anatole Litvak, Buddy Adler and Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation
results.description: Classic film from the play by Marcelle Maurette, adapted by Guy Bolton and screenplay by Arthur Laurents. The story is based on a factual account of the mystery that surrounded the Russian princess Anastasia, youngest daughter of Tzar Nicholas II, who along with her family was imprisoned and shot after the 1917 revolution. Or was she shot? Did Anastasia in fact live on? The scene is Paris in 1928 during the time of Russian Easter. A destitute and suicidal woman suffering from amnesia who remarkably resembles Princess Anastasia (Ingrid Bergman) is rescued by exiled Russian General Bounine (Yul Brynner). The suave, but forceful General, conspires to pass this woman off as the long-lost daughter of the Tzar for the sole purpose of benefiting from the Princess’s ten million pound inheritance. But there are many who remain sceptical, not least of all the Russian Grand Duchess (Helen Hayes), grandmother of the real Anastasia. An intriguing plot played out superbly by Bergman and Brynner but also made all the more intriguing following Bergman’s own Hollywood comeback from exile in Europe after her affair with Italian director, Roberto Rossellini. (Awards: Academy Awards, 1957, Ingrid Bergman for Best Actress in a Leading Role; Golden Globes, 1957, Ingrid Bergman for Best Motion Picture Actress - Drama)

results.title: An Interview with Brigadier John P.A. Deighton
results.brief_description: John Deighton admits that at 18, everyone believes that they are bulletproof but the adventure of war stops when people start dying. He believes that the instant replay effect and the televisation of the Vietnam War was a factor in its unpopularity. He remembers the poor treatment Vietnam vets received on their return and how unfair it was as they were just doing their job.

results.title: An Interview with Major General Jim Hughes
results.brief_description: Major General Jim Hughes joined the army just after World War II. Army life suited him and he served as a platoon commander in Korea in the 1950s. He details one particularly long Sunday, during this time, when his company was ambushed by the Chinese and resulted in him maturing considerably in one day.

results.title: Analyze this = Analyse this
results.creator_credit: Harold Ramis, Jane Rosenthal, Paula Weinstein, Village Roadshow Pictures and Warner Bros Pictures
results.brief_description: Mob boss Paul Vitti (Robert DeNiro) is having trouble sleeping on the eve of a planned meeting between rival Mafia gangs. His anxiety soon turns into a full blown panic attack prompting the tough guy to contact psychiatrist Ben Sobel (Billy Crystal). The neurotic Sobel initially refuses to take Vitti on as a patient but soon finds that the desperate criminal doesn’t take rejection well. Director Harold Ramis uses this comedic premise effectively, parodying the mobs ‘tough guy’ ethos, while lampooning an assortment of familiar gangster films. The casting of DeNiro is a joke in itself as the actor sends up his previous film incarnations as the quintessential Mafia ‘wiseguy’. Cast also includes Lisa Kudrow, Chazz Palminteri and Joe Viterelli.

results.title: Analects of Kung Phu: Book 1, The 69 Dialogues between the Lamp and the Shadow
results.credit_line:
Jason Phu
Three-channel video installation, 85 mins.
Edited by Conor Bateman
Mordant Family Moving Image Commission, ACMI Collection
results.brief_description: During times of uncertainty, people look for guidance. Jason Phu found it in martial arts films. By reclaiming wise sayings from movies and TV shows Analects of Kung Phu presents a moving image philosophy for surviving contemporary life.

constellations_primary.name: Jason Phu and genre-bending kung fu films
constellations_primary.description: Analects of Kung Phu work is a philosophical guide to life via martial arts films, drawing on his interest in Vietnamese and Chinese folklore, which inspires many of the films featured in this Constellation.

results.title_for_label: Analects of Kung Phu: Book 1, The 69 Dialogues between the Lamp and the Shadow
results.description:
“I want to create something that is genuinely useful but is also aware of its own representational fallacies and historical inaccuracies. I hope that people notice the highly personal nature of this work and feel inspired to make their own compendium of sayings to guide their own lives.” – Jason Phu

During times of uncertainty, people look for guidance. Jason Phu found it in martial arts films. By reclaiming wise sayings from movies and TV shows like Drunken Master (1978) and Avatar the Last Airbender (2005–08), Analects of Kung Phu presents a moving image philosophy for surviving contemporary life. Taught by action stars but inspired by classic Chinese texts like Lao Zi’s Dao De Jing, he questions whether these life lessons are genuinely useful. Phu is aware of how wisdom can be oversimplified and misused, how film subtitles miss the mark or even present a completely different narrative, and how we are guided in our day-to-day life by the movies we watch.

Leading Melbourne-based visual artist Jason Phu’s multi-disciplinary practice includes printmaking, installation, painting and video. Born in 1989 in Sydney, Australia, Phu lives and works in Melbourne, Australia. Phu’s artworks often explore Chinese histories in Australia, his own family history, and Chinese/Vietnamese folktales.

Jason Phu is the 2021 recipient of the Mordant Family Moving Image Commission for young Australian artists.

Read more

More than 200 kung fu films later, Jason Phu had his own movie to make by Kerrie O’Brien

My parents met at the fish market by Jason Phu in The Lifted Brow

Interview #34 — Jason Phu by Sophia Cai in Liminal

Storytelling with Jason Phu by Sabina McKenna in Acclaim

Who is Jason Phu? by Jane Albert in Broadsheet

results.title: An Interview with Shirley Cornish
results.brief_description: Shirley Cornish joined the army when a friend, from the store where she worked, said she would. She joined the Australian Womens Army Service and spent most of her life in the service of the army, and tells of her times there and friends made. Army life often bled into Shirley’s personal life, losing a rank in order to spend more time with her mother and, later, joining the Bentleigh War Widows and Widowed Mothers after her husband died. Shirley considers joining this association to be the best thing she ever did and even went on to become its president.

results.title: An Interview with Stan Guilfoyle
results.brief_description: When he was 13, Stan Guilfoyle was in an accident in which he nearly died. From then on he believed in seizing every moment. This enthusiasm for life took him to the Royal Australian Air Force, where he became proficient at flying, using only the instruments in his cockpit to navigate. He tells of his time in Indonesia during World War II and passionately shares his views on war.

results.title: An Interview with Brigadier Keith Rossi
results.brief_description: Brigadier Keith Rossi went to join up but needed to lie about his age to do so. He tells of his time in the army with humour, capturing the cameraderie that helped alleviate the horror of war. In his time serving, he went from the Middle East, to New Guinea and, later, Vietnam, from Private to Brigadier.
